sentences: But as time goes on, and their hearers advance in years, and come into closer contact with realities, and have learnt by sad experience to see and feel the truth of things, are not the greater part of them compelled to change many opinions which they formerly entertained, so that the great appears small to them, and the easy difficult, and all their dreamy speculations are overturned by the facts of life?

513.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is my view, as far as I can judge, although, at my age, I may be one of those who see things at a distance only.

514.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the wish of all of us, who are your friends, is and always will be to bring you as near to the truth as we can without the sad reality.

And now I should like you to tell me, whether the Sophist is not visibly a magician and imitator of true being; or are we still disposed to think that he may have a true knowledge of the various matters about which he disputes?

515.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: But how can he, Stranger?
Is there any doubt, after what has been said, that he is to be located in one of the divisions of children's play?

516.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then we must place him in the class of magicians and mimics.

517.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly we must.

518.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And now our business is not to let the animal out, for we have got him in a sort of dialectical net, and there is one thing which he decidedly will not escape.

519.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What is that?

520.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The inference that he is a juggler.

521.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Precisely my own opinion of him.

522.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then, clearly, we ought as soon as possible to divide the image-making art, and go down into the net, and, if the Sophist does not run away from us, to seize him according to orders and deliver him over to reason, who is the lord of the hunt, and proclaim the capture of him; and if he creeps into the recesses of the imitative art, and secretes himself in one of them, to divide again and follow him up until in some sub-section of imitation he is caught.
For our method of tackling each and all is one which neither he nor any other creature will ever escape in triumph.

523.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Well said; and let us do as you propose.

524.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Well, then, pursuing the same analytic method as before, I think that I can discern two divisions of the imitative art, but I am not as yet able to see in which of them the desired form is to be found.

525.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Will you tell me first what are the two divisions of which you are speaking?

526.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: One is the art of likeness-making;—generally a likeness of anything is made by producing a copy which is executed according to the proportions of the original, similar in length and breadth and depth, each thing receiving also its appropriate colour.

527.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Is not this always the aim of imitation?

528.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Not always; in works either of sculpture or of painting, which are of any magnitude, there is a certain degree of deception; for artists were to give the true proportions of their fair works, the upper part, which is farther off, would appear to be out of proportion in comparison with the lower, which is nearer; and so they give up the truth in their images and make only the proportions which appear to be beautiful, disregarding the real ones.

529.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

530.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And that which being other is also like, may we not fairly call a likeness or image?

531.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

532.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And may we not, as I did just now, call that part of the imitative art which is concerned with making such images the art of likeness-making?

533.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Let that be the name.

534.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And what shall we call those resemblances of the beautiful, which appear such owing to the unfavourable position of the spectator, whereas if a person had the power of getting a correct view of works of such magnitude, they would appear not even like that to which they profess to be like?
May we not call these 'appearances,' since they appear only and are not really like?

535.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

536.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: There is a great deal of this kind of thing in painting, and in all imitation.

537.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course.

538.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And may we not fairly call the sort of art, which produces an appearance and not an image, phantastic art?

539.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Most fairly.

540.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: These then are the two kinds of image-making—the art of making likenesses, and phantastic or the art of making appearances?

541.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

542.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I was doubtful before in which of them I should place the Sophist, nor am I even now able to see clearly; verily he is a wonderful and inscrutable creature.
And now in the cleverest manner he has got into an impossible place.

543.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, he has.

544.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Do you speak advisedly, or are you carried away at the moment by the habit of assenting into giving a hasty answer?

545.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: May I ask to what you are referring?

546.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: My dear friend, we are engaged in a very difficult speculation—there can be no doubt of that; for how a thing can appear and seem, and not be, or how a man can say a thing which is not true, has always been and still remains a very perplexing question.
Can any one say or think that falsehood really exists, and avoid being caught in a contradiction?
Indeed, Theaetetus, the task is a difficult one.

547.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Why?

548.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: He who says that falsehood exists has the audacity to assert the being of not-being; for this is implied in the possibility of falsehood.

But, my boy, in the days when I was a boy, the great Parmenides protested against this doctrine, and to the end of his life he continued to inculcate the same lesson—always repeating both in verse and out of verse:
'Keep your mind from this way of enquiry, for never will you show that not-being is.'
Such is his testimony, which is confirmed by the very expression when sifted a little.
Would you object to begin with the consideration of the words themselves?

551.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Never mind about me; I am only desirous that you should carry on the argument in the best way, and that you should take me with you.

552.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Very good; and now say, do we venture to utter the forbidden word 'not-being'?

553.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly we do.

554.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let us be serious then, and consider the question neither in strife nor play:  suppose that one of the hearers of Parmenides was asked, 'To what is the term "not-being" to be applied?
'—do you know what sort of object he would single out in reply, and what answer he would make to the enquirer?

555.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is a difficult question, and one not to be answered at all by a person like myself.

556.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: There is at any rate no difficulty in seeing that the predicate 'not-being' is not applicable to any being.

557.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: None, certainly.

558.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And if not to being, then not to something.

559.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course not.

560.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: It is also plain, that in speaking of something we speak of being, for to speak of an abstract something naked and isolated from all being is impossible.

561.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Impossible.

562.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: You mean by assenting to imply that he who says something must say some one thing?

563.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

564.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Some in the singular (ti) you would say is the sign of one, some in the dual (tine) of two, some in the plural (tines) of many?

565.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Exactly.

566.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then he who says 'not something' must say absolutely nothing.

567.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Most assuredly.

568.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And as we cannot admit that a man speaks and says nothing, he who says 'not-being' does not speak at all.

569.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: The difficulty of the argument can no further go.

570.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Not yet, my friend, is the time for such a word; for there still remains of all perplexities the first and greatest, touching the very foundation of the matter.

571.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What do you mean?
Do not be afraid to speak.

572.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: To that which is, may be attributed some other thing which is?

573.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

574.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But can anything which is, be attributed to that which is not?

575.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Impossible.

576.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And all number is to be reckoned among things which are?

577.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, surely number, if anything, has a real existence.

578.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then we must not attempt to attribute to not-being number either in the singular or plural?

579.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: The argument implies that we should be wrong in doing so.

580.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But how can a man either express in words or even conceive in thought things which are not or a thing which is not without number?

581.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How indeed?

582.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When we speak of things which are not, are we not attributing plurality to not-being?

583.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

584.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But, on the other hand, when we say 'what is not,' do we not attribute unity?

585.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Manifestly.

586.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Nevertheless, we maintain that you may not and ought not to attribute being to not-being?

587.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Most true.

588.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Do you see, then, that not-being in itself can neither be spoken, uttered, or thought, but that it is unthinkable, unutterable, unspeakable, indescribable?

589.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

590.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But, if so, I was wrong in telling you just now that the difficulty which was coming is the greatest of all.

591.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What!
is there a greater still behind?

592.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Well, I am surprised, after what has been said already, that you do not see the difficulty in which he who would refute the notion of not-being is involved.
For he is compelled to contradict himself as soon as he makes the attempt.

593.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What do you mean?
Speak more clearly.

594.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Do not expect clearness from me.
For I, who maintain that not-being has no part either in the one or many, just now spoke and am still speaking of not-being as one; for I say 'not-being.'
Do you understand?

595.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

596.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And a little while ago I said that not-being is unutterable, unspeakable, indescribable:  do you follow?

597.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I do after a fashion.

598.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When I introduced the word 'is,' did I not contradict what I said before?

599.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Clearly.

600.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And in using the singular verb, did I not speak of not-being as one?

601.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

602.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And when I spoke of not-being as indescribable and unspeakable and unutterable, in using each of these words in the singular, did I not refer to not-being as one?

603.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

604.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And yet we say that, strictly speaking, it should not be defined as one or many, and should not even be called 'it,' for the use of the word 'it' would imply a form of unity.

605.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

606.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: How, then, can any one put any faith in me?
For now, as always, I am unequal to the refutation of not-being.
And therefore, as I was saying, do not look to me for the right way of speaking about not-being; but come, let us try the experiment with you.

607.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What do you mean?

608.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Make a noble effort, as becomes youth, and endeavour with all your might to speak of not-being in a right manner, without introducing into it either existence or unity or plurality.

609.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: It would be a strange boldness in me which would attempt the task when I see you thus discomfited.

610.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Say no more of ourselves; but until we find some one or other who can speak of not-being without number, we must acknowledge that the Sophist is a clever rogue who will not be got out of his hole.

611.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Most true.

612.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And if we say to him that he professes an art of making appearances, he will grapple with us and retort our argument upon ourselves; and when we call him an image-maker he will say, 'Pray what do you mean at all by an image?
'—and I should like to know, Theaetetus, how we can possibly answer the younker's question?

613.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: We shall doubtless tell him of the images which are reflected in water or in mirrors; also of sculptures, pictures, and other duplicates.

614.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I see, Theaetetus, that you have never made the acquaintance of the Sophist.

615.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Why do you think so?

616.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: He will make believe to have his eyes shut, or to have none.

617.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What do you mean?

618.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When you tell him of something existing in a mirror, or in sculpture, and address him as though he had eyes, he will laugh you to scorn, and will pretend that he knows nothing of mirrors and streams, or of sight at all; he will say that he is asking about an idea.

619.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What can he mean?

620.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The common notion pervading all these objects, which you speak of as many, and yet call by the single name of image, as though it were the unity under which they were all included.
How will you maintain your ground against him?

621.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How, Stranger, can I describe an image except as something fashioned in the likeness of the true?

622.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And do you mean this something to be some other true thing, or what do you mean?

623.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly not another true thing, but only a resemblance.

624.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And you mean by true that which really is?

625.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

626.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the not true is that which is the opposite of the true?

627.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Exactly.

628.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: A resemblance, then, is not really real, if, as you say, not true?

629.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Nay, but it is in a certain sense.

630.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: You mean to say, not in a true sense?

631.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes; it is in reality only an image.

632.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then what we call an image is in reality really unreal.

633.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: In what a strange complication of being and not-being we are involved!

634.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Strange!
I should think so.
See how, by his reciprocation of opposites, the many-headed Sophist has compelled us, quite against our will, to admit the existence of not-being.

635.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, indeed, I see.

636.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The difficulty is how to define his art without falling into a contradiction.

637.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How do you mean?
And where does the danger lie?

638.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When we say that he deceives us with an illusion, and that his art is illusory, do we mean that our soul is led by his art to think falsely, or what do we mean?

639.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: There is nothing else to be said.

640.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Again, false opinion is that form of opinion which thinks the opposite of the truth: —You would assent?

641.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

642.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: You mean to say that false opinion thinks what is not?

643.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course.

644.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Does false opinion think that things which are not are not, or that in a certain sense they are?

645.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Things that are not must be imagined to exist in a certain sense, if any degree of falsehood is to be possible.

646.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And does not false opinion also think that things which most certainly exist do not exist at all?

647.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

648.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And here, again, is falsehood?

649.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Falsehood—yes.

650.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And in like manner, a false proposition will be deemed to be one which asserts the non-existence of things which are, and the existence of things which are not.

651.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: There is no other way in which a false proposition can arise.

652.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: There is not; but the Sophist will deny these statements.
And indeed how can any rational man assent to them, when the very expressions which we have just used were before acknowledged by us to be unutterable, unspeakable, indescribable, unthinkable?
Do you see his point, Theaetetus?

653.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course he will say that we are contradicting ourselves when we hazard the assertion, that falsehood exists in opinion and in words; for in maintaining this, we are compelled over and over again to assert being of not-being, which we admitted just now to be an utter impossibility.

654.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: How well you remember!

And now it is high time to hold a consultation as to what we ought to do about the Sophist; for if we persist in looking for him in the class of false workers and magicians, you see that the handles for objection and the difficulties which will arise are very numerous and obvious.

655.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: They are indeed.

656.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: We have gone through but a very small portion of them, and they are really infinite.

657.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: If that is the case, we cannot possibly catch the Sophist.

658.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Shall we then be so faint-hearted as to give him up?

659.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly not, I should say, if we can get the slightest hold upon him.

660.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Will you then forgive me, and, as your words imply, not be altogether displeased if I flinch a little from the grasp of such a sturdy argument?

661.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: To be sure I will.

662.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I have a yet more urgent request to make.

663.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Which is—?

664.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: That you will promise not to regard me as a parricide.

665.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: And why?

666.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Because, in self-defence, I must test the philosophy of my father Parmenides, and try to prove by main force that in a certain sense not-being is, and that being, on the other hand, is not.

667.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Some attempt of the kind is clearly needed.

668.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Yes, a blind man, as they say, might see that, and, unless these questions are decided in one way or another, no one when he speaks of false words, or false opinion, or idols, or images, or imitations, or appearances, or about the arts which are concerned with them; can avoid falling into ridiculous contradictions.

669.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Most true.

670.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And therefore I must venture to lay hands on my father's argument; for if I am to be over-scrupulous, I shall have to give the matter up.

671.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Nothing in the world should ever induce us to do so.

672.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I have a third little request which I wish to make.

673.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What is it?

674.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: You heard me say what I have always felt and still feel—that I have no heart for this argument?

675.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I did.

676.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I tremble at the thought of what I have said, and expect that you will deem me mad, when you hear of my sudden changes and shiftings; let me therefore observe, that I am examining the question entirely out of regard for you.

677.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: There is no reason for you to fear that I shall impute any impropriety to you, if you attempt this refutation and proof; take heart, therefore, and proceed.

678.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And where shall I begin the perilous enterprise?
I think that the road which I must take is—

679.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Which?—Let me hear.

680.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I think that we had better, first of all, consider the points which at present are regarded as self-evident, lest we may have fallen into some confusion, and be too ready to assent to one another, fancying that we are quite clear about them.

681.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Say more distinctly what you mean.

682.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I think that Parmenides, and all ever yet undertook to determine the number and nature of existences, talked to us in rather a light and easy strain.

683.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How?

684.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: As if we had been children, to whom they repeated each his own mythus or story;—one said that there were three principles, and that at one time there was war between certain of them; and then again there was peace, and they were married and begat children, and brought them up; and another spoke of two principles,—a moist and a dry, or a hot and a cold, and made them marry and cohabit.
The Eleatics, however, in our part of the world, say that all things are many in name, but in nature one; this is their mythus, which goes back to Xenophanes, and is even older.

Then there are Ionian, and in more recent times Sicilian muses, who have arrived at the conclusion that to unite the two principles is safer, and to say that being is one and many, and that these are held together by enmity and friendship, ever parting, ever meeting, as the severer Muses assert, while the gentler ones do not insist on the perpetual strife and peace, but admit a relaxation and alternation of them; peace and unity sometimes prevailing under the sway of Aphrodite, and then again plurality and war, by reason of a principle of strife.
Whether any of them spoke the truth in all this is hard to determine; besides, antiquity and famous men should have reverence, and not be liable to accusations so serious.
Yet one thing may be said of them without offence—

685.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What thing?

686.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: That they went on their several ways disdaining to notice people like ourselves; they did not care whether they took us with them, or left us behind them.

687.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How do you mean?

688.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I mean to say, that when they talk of one, two, or more elements, which are or have become or are becoming, or again of heat mingling with cold, assuming in some other part of their works separations and mixtures,—tell me, Theaetetus, do you understand what they mean by these expressions?
When I was a younger man, I used to fancy that I understood quite well what was meant by the term 'not-being,' which is our present subject of dispute; and now you see in what a fix we are about it.

689.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I see.

690.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And very likely we have been getting into the same perplexity about 'being,' and yet may fancy that when anybody utters the word, we understand him quite easily, although we do not know about not-being.
But we may be; equally ignorant of both.

691.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I dare say.

692.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the same may be said of all the terms just mentioned.

693.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

694.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The consideration of most of them may be deferred; but we had better now discuss the chief captain and leader of them.

695.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of what are you speaking?
You clearly think that we must first investigate what people mean by the word 'being.'

696.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: You follow close at my heels, Theaetetus.
For the right method, I conceive, will be to call into our presence the dualistic philosophers and to interrogate them.

'Come,' we will say, 'Ye, who affirm that hot and cold or any other two principles are the universe, what is this term which you apply to both of them, and what do you mean when you say that both and each of them "are"?
How are we to understand the word "are"?
Upon your view, are we to suppose that there is a third principle over and above the other two,—three in all, and not two?

For clearly you cannot say that one of the two principles is being, and yet attribute being equally to both of them; for, if you did, whichever of the two is identified with being, will comprehend the other; and so they will be one and not two.'

697.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very true.

698.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But perhaps you mean to give the name of 'being' to both of them together?

699.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite likely.

700.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: 'Then, friends,' we shall reply to them, 'the answer is plainly that the two will still be resolved into one.'

701.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Most true.

702.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: 'Since, then, we are in a difficulty, please to tell us what you mean, when you speak of being; for there can be no doubt that you always from the first understood your own meaning, whereas we once thought that we understood you, but now we are in a great strait.
Please to begin by explaining this matter to us, and let us no longer fancy that we understand you, when we entirely misunderstand you.'
There will be no impropriety in our demanding an answer to this question, either of the dualists or of the pluralists?

703.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly not.

704.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And what about the assertors of the oneness of the all—must we not endeavour to ascertain from them what they mean by 'being'?

705.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: By all means.

706.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then let them answer this question:  One, you say, alone is?
'Yes,' they will reply.

707.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

708.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And there is something which you call 'being'?

709.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: 'Yes.'

710.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And is being the same as one, and do you apply two names to the same thing?

711.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What will be their answer, Stranger?

712.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: It is clear, Theaetetus, that he who asserts the unity of being will find a difficulty in answering this or any other question.

713.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Why so?

714.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: To admit of two names, and to affirm that there is nothing but unity, is surely ridiculous?

715.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

716.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And equally irrational to admit that a name is anything?

717.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How so?

718.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: To distinguish the name from the thing, implies duality.

719.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

720.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And yet he who identifies the name with the thing will be compelled to say that it is the name of nothing, or if he says that it is the name of something, even then the name will only be the name of a name, and of nothing else.

721.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

722.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the one will turn out to be only one of one, and being absolute unity, will represent a mere name.

723.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

724.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And would they say that the whole is other than the one that is, or the same with it?

725.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: To be sure they would, and they actually say so.

726.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: If being is a whole, as Parmenides sings,—
'Every way like unto the fullness of a well-rounded sphere, Evenly balanced from the centre on every side, And must needs be neither greater nor less in any way, Neither on this side nor on that—'
then being has a centre and extremes, and, having these, must also have parts.

729.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

730.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Yet that which has parts may have the attribute of unity in all the parts, and in this way being all and a whole, may be one?

731.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

732.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But that of which this is the condition cannot be absolute unity?

733.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Why not?

734.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Because, according to right reason, that which is truly one must be affirmed to be absolutely indivisible.

735.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

736.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But this indivisible, if made up of many parts, will contradict reason.

737.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I understand.

738.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Shall we say that being is one and a whole, because it has the attribute of unity?
Or shall we say that being is not a whole at all?

739.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is a hard alternative to offer.

740.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Most true; for being, having in a certain sense the attribute of one, is yet proved not to be the same as one, and the all is therefore more than one.

741.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

742.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And yet if being be not a whole, through having the attribute of unity, and there be such a thing as an absolute whole, being lacks something of its own nature?

743.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

744.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Upon this view, again, being, having a defect of being, will become not-being?

745.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

746.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And, again, the all becomes more than one, for being and the whole will each have their separate nature.

747.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

748.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But if the whole does not exist at all, all the previous difficulties remain the same, and there will be the further difficulty, that besides having no being, being can never have come into being.

749.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Why so?

750.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Because that which comes into being always comes into being as a whole, so that he who does not give whole a place among beings, cannot speak either of essence or generation as existing.

751.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, that certainly appears to be true.

752.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Again; how can that which is not a whole have any quantity?
For that which is of a certain quantity must necessarily be the whole of that quantity.

753.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Exactly.

754.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And there will be innumerable other points, each of them causing infinite trouble to him who says that being is either one or two.

755.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: The difficulties which are dawning upon us prove this; for one objection connects with another, and they are always involving what has preceded in a greater and worse perplexity.

756.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: We are far from having exhausted the more exact thinkers who treat of being and not-being.

But let us be content to leave them, and proceed to view those who speak less precisely; and we shall find as the result of all, that the nature of being is quite as difficult to comprehend as that of not-being.

757.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Then now we will go to the others.

758.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: There appears to be a sort of war of Giants and Gods going on amongst them; they are fighting with one another about the nature of essence.

759.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How is that?

760.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Some of them are dragging down all things from heaven and from the unseen to earth, and they literally grasp in their hands rocks and oaks; of these they lay hold, and obstinately maintain, that the things only which can be touched or handled have being or essence, because they define being and body as one, and if any one else says that what is not a body exists they altogether despise him, and will hear of nothing but body.

761.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I have often met with such men, and terrible fellows they are.

762.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And that is the reason why their opponents cautiously defend themselves from above, out of an unseen world, mightily contending that true essence consists of certain intelligible and incorporeal ideas; the bodies of the materialists, which by them are maintained to be the very truth, they break up into little bits by their arguments, and affirm them to be, not essence, but generation and motion.
Between the two armies, Theaetetus, there is always an endless conflict raging concerning these matters.

763.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

764.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let us ask each party in turn, to give an account of that which they call essence.

765.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How shall we get it out of them?

766.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: With those who make being to consist in ideas, there will be less difficulty, for they are civil people enough; but there will be very great difficulty, or rather an absolute impossibility, in getting an opinion out of those who drag everything down to matter.
Shall I tell you what we must do?

767.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What?

768.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let us, if we can, really improve them; but if this is not possible, let us imagine them to be better than they are, and more willing to answer in accordance with the rules of argument, and then their opinion will be more worth having; for that which better men acknowledge has more weight than that which is acknowledged by inferior men.
Moreover we are no respecters of persons, but seekers after truth.

769.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very good.

770.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then now, on the supposition that they are improved, let us ask them to state their views, and do you interpret them.

771.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Agreed.

772.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let them say whether they would admit that there is such a thing as a mortal animal.

773.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course they would.

774.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And do they not acknowledge this to be a body having a soul?

775.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly they do.

776.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Meaning to say that the soul is something which exists?

777.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

778.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And do they not say that one soul is just, and another unjust, and that one soul is wise, and another foolish?

779.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

780.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And that the just and wise soul becomes just and wise by the possession of justice and wisdom, and the opposite under opposite circumstances?

781.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, they do.

782.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But surely that which may be present or may be absent will be admitted by them to exist?

783.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

784.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And, allowing that justice, wisdom, the other virtues, and their opposites exist, as well as a soul in which they inhere, do they affirm any of them to be visible and tangible, or are they all invisible?

785.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: They would say that hardly any of them are visible.

786.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And would they say that they are corporeal?

787.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: They would distinguish:  the soul would be said by them to have a body; but as to the other qualities of justice, wisdom, and the like, about which you asked, they would not venture either to deny their existence, or to maintain that they were all corporeal.

788.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Verily, Theaetetus, I perceive a great improvement in them; the real aborigines, children of the dragon's teeth, would have been deterred by no shame at all, but would have obstinately asserted that nothing is which they are not able to squeeze in their hands.

789.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is pretty much their notion.

790.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let us push the question; for if they will admit that any, even the smallest particle of being, is incorporeal, it is enough; they must then say what that nature is which is common to both the corporeal and incorporeal, and which they have in their mind's eye when they say of both of them that they 'are.'
Perhaps they may be in a difficulty; and if this is the case, there is a possibility that they may accept a notion of ours respecting the nature of being, having nothing of their own to offer.

791.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What is the notion?
Tell me, and we shall soon see.

792.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: My notion would be, that anything which possesses any sort of power to affect another, or to be affected by another, if only for a single moment, however trifling the cause and however slight the effect, has real existence; and I hold that the definition of being is simply power.

793.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: They accept your suggestion, having nothing better of their own to offer.

794.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Very good; perhaps we, as well as they, may one day change our minds; but, for the present, this may be regarded as the understanding which is established with them.

795.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Agreed.

796.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let us now go to the friends of ideas; of their opinions, too, you shall be the interpreter.

797.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I will.

798.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: To them we say—You would distinguish essence from generation?

799.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: 'Yes,' they reply.

800.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And you would allow that we participate in generation with the body, and through perception, but we participate with the soul through thought in true essence; and essence you would affirm to be always the same and immutable, whereas generation or becoming varies?

801.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes; that is what we should affirm.

802.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Well, fair sirs, we say to them, what is this participation, which you assert of both?
Do you agree with our recent definition?

803.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What definition?

804.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: We said that being was an active or passive energy, arising out of a certain power which proceeds from elements meeting with one another.
Perhaps your ears, Theaetetus, may fail to catch their answer, which I recognize because I have been accustomed to hear it.

805.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: And what is their answer?

806.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: They deny the truth of what we were just now saying to the aborigines about existence.

807.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What was that?

808.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Any power of doing or suffering in a degree however slight was held by us to be a sufficient definition of being?

809.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

810.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: They deny this, and say that the power of doing or suffering is confined to becoming, and that neither power is applicable to being.

811.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: And is there not some truth in what they say?

812.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Yes; but our reply will be, that we want to ascertain from them more distinctly, whether they further admit that the soul knows, and that being or essence is known.

813.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: There can be no doubt that they say so.

814.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And is knowing and being known doing or suffering, or both, or is the one doing and the other suffering, or has neither any share in either?

815.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Clearly, neither has any share in either; for if they say anything else, they will contradict themselves.

816.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I understand; but they will allow that if to know is active, then, of course, to be known is passive.
And on this view being, in so far as it is known, is acted upon by knowledge, and is therefore in motion; for that which is in a state of rest cannot be acted upon, as we affirm.

817.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

818.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And, O heavens, can we ever be made to believe that motion and life and soul and mind are not present with perfect being?
Can we imagine that being is devoid of life and mind, and exists in awful unmeaningness an everlasting fixture?

819.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That would be a dreadful thing to admit, Stranger.

820.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But shall we say that has mind and not life?

821.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How is that possible?

822.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Or shall we say that both inhere in perfect being, but that it has no soul which contains them?

823.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: And in what other way can it contain them?

824.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Or that being has mind and life and soul, but although endowed with soul remains absolutely unmoved?

825.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: All three suppositions appear to me to be irrational.

826.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Under being, then, we must include motion, and that which is moved.

827.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

828.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then, Theaetetus, our inference is, that if there is no motion, neither is there any mind anywhere, or about anything or belonging to any one.

829.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

830.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And yet this equally follows, if we grant that all things are in motion—upon this view too mind has no existence.

831.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How so?

832.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Do you think that sameness of condition and mode and subject could ever exist without a principle of rest?

833.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly not.

834.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Can you see how without them mind could exist, or come into existence anywhere?

835.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: No.

836.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And surely contend we must in every possible way against him who would annihilate knowledge and reason and mind, and yet ventures to speak confidently about anything.

837.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, with all our might.

838.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then the philosopher, who has the truest reverence for these qualities, cannot possibly accept the notion of those who say that the whole is at rest, either as unity or in many forms:  and he will be utterly deaf to those who assert universal motion.
As children say entreatingly 'Give us both,' so he will include both the moveable and immoveable in his definition of being and all.

839.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Most true.

840.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And now, do we seem to have gained a fair notion of being?

841.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes truly.

842.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Alas, Theaetetus, methinks that we are now only beginning to see the real difficulty of the enquiry into the nature of it.

843.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What do you mean?

844.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: O my friend, do you not see that nothing can exceed our ignorance, and yet we fancy that we are saying something good?

845.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I certainly thought that we were; and I do not at all understand how we never found out our desperate case.

846.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Reflect:  after having made these admissions, may we not be justly asked the same questions which we ourselves were asking of those who said that all was hot and cold?

847.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What were they?
Will you recall them to my mind?

848.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: To be sure I will, and I will remind you of them, by putting the same questions to you which I did to them, and then we shall get on.

849.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

850.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Would you not say that rest and motion are in the most entire opposition to one another?

851.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course.

852.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And yet you would say that both and either of them equally are?

853.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I should.

854.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And when you admit that both or either of them are, do you mean to say that both or either of them are in motion?

855.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly not.

856.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Or do you wish to imply that they are both at rest, when you say that they are?

857.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course not.

858.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then you conceive of being as some third and distinct nature, under which rest and motion are alike included; and, observing that they both participate in being, you declare that they are.

859.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Truly we seem to have an intimation that being is some third thing, when we say that rest and motion are.

860.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then being is not the combination of rest and motion, but something different from them.

861.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: So it would appear.

862.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Being, then, according to its own nature, is neither in motion nor at rest.

863.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is very much the truth.

864.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Where, then, is a man to look for help who would have any clear or fixed notion of being in his mind?

865.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Where, indeed?

866.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I scarcely think that he can look anywhere; for that which is not in motion must be at rest, and again, that which is not at rest must be in motion; but being is placed outside of both these classes.
Is this possible?

867.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Utterly impossible.

868.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Here, then, is another thing which we ought to bear in mind.

869.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What?

870.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When we were asked to what we were to assign the appellation of not-being, we were in the greatest difficulty: —do you remember?

871.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: To be sure.

872.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And are we not now in as great a difficulty about being?

873.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I should say, Stranger, that we are in one which is, if possible, even greater.

874.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then let us acknowledge the difficulty; and as being and not-being are involved in the same perplexity, there is hope that when the one appears more or less distinctly, the other will equally appear; and if we are able to see neither, there may still be a chance of steering our way in between them, without any great discredit.

875.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very good.

876.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let us enquire, then, how we come to predicate many names of the same thing.

877.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Give an example.

878.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I mean that we speak of man, for example, under many names—that we attribute to him colours and forms and magnitudes and virtues and vices, in all of which instances and in ten thousand others we not only speak of him as a man, but also as good, and having numberless other attributes, and in the same way anything else which we originally supposed to be one is described by us as many, and under many names.

879.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is true.

880.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And thus we provide a rich feast for tyros, whether young or old; for there is nothing easier than to argue that the one cannot be many, or the many one; and great is their delight in denying that a man is good; for man, they insist, is man and good is good.

I dare say that you have met with persons who take an interest in such matters—they are often elderly men, whose meagre sense is thrown into amazement by these discoveries of theirs, which they believe to be the height of wisdom.

881.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly, I have.

882.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then, not to exclude any one who has ever speculated at all upon the nature of being, let us put our questions to them as well as to our former friends.

883.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What questions?

884.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Shall we refuse to attribute being to motion and rest, or anything to anything, and assume that they do not mingle, and are incapable of participating in one another?
Or shall we gather all into one class of things communicable with one another?
Or are some things communicable and others not?—Which of these alternatives, Theaetetus, will they prefer?

885.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I have nothing to answer on their behalf.
Suppose that you take all these hypotheses in turn, and see what are the consequences which follow from each of them.

886.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Very good, and first let us assume them to say that nothing is capable of participating in anything else in any respect; in that case rest and motion cannot participate in being at all.

887.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: They cannot.

888.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But would either of them be if not participating in being?

889.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: No.

890.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then by this admission everything is instantly overturned, as well the doctrine of universal motion as of universal rest, and also the doctrine of those who distribute being into immutable and everlasting kinds; for all these add on a notion of being, some affirming that things 'are' truly in motion, and others that they 'are' truly at rest.

891.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Just so.

892.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Again, those who would at one time compound, and at another resolve all things, whether making them into one and out of one creating infinity, or dividing them into finite elements, and forming compounds out of these; whether they suppose the processes of creation to be successive or continuous, would be talking nonsense in all this if there were no admixture.

893.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

894.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Most ridiculous of all will the men themselves be who want to carry out the argument and yet forbid us to call anything, because participating in some affection from another, by the name of that other.

895.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Why so?

896.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Why, because they are compelled to use the words 'to be,' 'apart,' 'from others,' 'in itself,' and ten thousand more, which they cannot give up, but must make the connecting links of discourse; and therefore they do not require to be refuted by others, but their enemy, as the saying is, inhabits the same house with them; they are always carrying about with them an adversary, like the wonderful ventriloquist, Eurycles, who out of their own bellies audibly contradicts them.

897.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Precisely so; a very true and exact illustration.

898.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And now, if we suppose that all things have the power of communion with one another—what will follow?

899.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Even I can solve that riddle.

900.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: How?

901.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Why, because motion itself would be at rest, and rest again in motion, if they could be attributed to one another.

902.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But this is utterly impossible.

903.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course.

904.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then only the third hypothesis remains.

905.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

906.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: For, surely, either all things have communion with all; or nothing with any other thing; or some things communicate with some things and others not.

907.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

908.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And two out of these three suppositions have been found to be impossible.

909.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

910.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Every one then, who desires to answer truly, will adopt the third and remaining hypothesis of the communion of some with some.

911.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

912.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: This communion of some with some may be illustrated by the case of letters; for some letters do not fit each other, while others do.

913.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course.

914.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the vowels, especially, are a sort of bond which pervades all the other letters, so that without a vowel one consonant cannot be joined to another.

915.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

916.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But does every one know what letters will unite with what?
Or is art required in order to do so?

917.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Art is required.

918.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: What art?

919.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: The art of grammar.

920.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And is not this also true of sounds high and low?—Is not he who has the art to know what sounds mingle, a musician, and he who is ignorant, not a musician?

921.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

922.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And we shall find this to be generally true of art or the absence of art.

923.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course.

924.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And as classes are admitted by us in like manner to be some of them capable and others incapable of intermixture, must not he who would rightly show what kinds will unite and what will not, proceed by the help of science in the path of argument?

And will he not ask if the connecting links are universal, and so capable of intermixture with all things; and again, in divisions, whether there are not other universal classes, which make them possible?

925.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: To be sure he will require science, and, if I am not mistaken, the very greatest of all sciences.

926.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: How are we to call it?
By Zeus, have we not lighted unwittingly upon our free and noble science, and in looking for the Sophist have we not entertained the philosopher unawares?

927.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What do you mean?

928.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Should we not say that the division according to classes, which neither makes the same other, nor makes other the same, is the business of the dialectical science?

929.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is what we should say.

930.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then, surely, he who can divide rightly is able to see clearly one form pervading a scattered multitude, and many different forms contained under one higher form; and again, one form knit together into a single whole and pervading many such wholes, and many forms, existing only in separation and isolation.
This is the knowledge of classes which determines where they can have communion with one another and where not.

931.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

932.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the art of dialectic would be attributed by you only to the philosopher pure and true?

933.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Who but he can be worthy?

934.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: In this region we shall always discover the philosopher, if we look for him; like the Sophist, he is not easily discovered, but for a different reason.

935.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: For what reason?

936.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Because the Sophist runs away into the darkness of not-being, in which he has learned by habit to feel about, and cannot be discovered because of the darkness of the place.
Is not that true?

937.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: It seems to be so.

938.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the philosopher, always holding converse through reason with the idea of being, is also dark from excess of light; for the souls of the many have no eye which can endure the vision of the divine.

939.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes; that seems to be quite as true as the other.

940.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Well, the philosopher may hereafter be more fully considered by us, if we are disposed; but the Sophist must clearly not be allowed to escape until we have had a good look at him.

941.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very good.

942.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Since, then, we are agreed that some classes have a communion with one another, and others not, and some have communion with a few and others with many, and that there is no reason why some should not have universal communion with all, let us now pursue the enquiry, as the argument suggests, not in relation to all ideas, lest the multitude of them should confuse us, but let us select a few of those which are reckoned to be the principal ones, and consider their several natures and their capacity of communion with one another, in order that if we are not able to apprehend with perfect clearness the notions of being and not-being, we may at least not fall short in the consideration of them, so far as they come within the scope of the present enquiry, if peradventure we may be allowed to assert the reality of not-being, and yet escape unscathed.

943.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: We must do so.

944.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The most important of all the genera are those which we were just now mentioning—being and rest and motion.

945.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, by far.

946.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And two of these are, as we affirm, incapable of communion with one another.

947.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite incapable.

948.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Whereas being surely has communion with both of them, for both of them are?

949.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course.

950.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: That makes up three of them.

951.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: To be sure.

952.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And each of them is other than the remaining two, but the same with itself.

953.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

954.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But then, what is the meaning of these two words, 'same' and 'other'?

Are they two new kinds other than the three, and yet always of necessity intermingling with them, and are we to have five kinds instead of three; or when we speak of the same and other, are we unconsciously speaking of one of the three first kinds?

955.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very likely we are.

956.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But, surely, motion and rest are neither the other nor the same.

957.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How is that?

958.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Whatever we attribute to motion and rest in common, cannot be either of them.

959.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Why not?

960.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Because motion would be at rest and rest in motion, for either of them, being predicated of both, will compel the other to change into the opposite of its own nature, because partaking of its opposite.

961.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

962.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Yet they surely both partake of the same and of the other?

963.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

964.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then we must not assert that motion, any more than rest, is either the same or the other.

965.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: No; we must not.

966.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But are we to conceive that being and the same are identical?

967.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Possibly.

968.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But if they are identical, then again in saying that motion and rest have being, we should also be saying that they are the same.

969.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Which surely cannot be.

970.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then being and the same cannot be one.

971.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Scarcely.

972.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then we may suppose the same to be a fourth class, which is now to be added to the three others.

973.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

974.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And shall we call the other a fifth class?
Or should we consider being and other to be two names of the same class?

975.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very likely.

976.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But you would agree, if I am not mistaken, that existences are relative as well as absolute?

977.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

978.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the other is always relative to other?

979.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

980.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But this would not be the case unless being and the other entirely differed; for, if the other, like being, were absolute as well as relative, then there would have been a kind of other which was not other than other.
And now we find that what is other must of necessity be what it is in relation to some other.

981.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is the true state of the case.

982.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then we must admit the other as the fifth of our selected classes.

983.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

984.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the fifth class pervades all classes, for they all differ from one another, not by reason of their own nature, but because they partake of the idea of the other.

985.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

986.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then let us now put the case with reference to each of the five.

987.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How?

988.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: First there is motion, which we affirm to be absolutely 'other' than rest:  what else can we say?

989.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: It is so.

990.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And therefore is not rest.

991.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly not.

992.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And yet is, because partaking of being.

993.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

994.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Again, motion is other than the same?

995.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Just so.

996.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And is therefore not the same.

997.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: It is not.

998.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Yet, surely, motion is the same, because all things partake of the same.

999.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very true.

1000.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then we must admit, and not object to say, that motion is the same and is not the same, for we do not apply the terms 'same' and 'not the same,' in the same sense; but we call it the 'same,' in relation to itself, because partaking of the same; and not the same, because having communion with the other, it is thereby severed from the same, and has become not that but other, and is therefore rightly spoken of as 'not the same.'

1001.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: To be sure.

1002.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And if absolute motion in any point of view partook of rest, there would be no absurdity in calling motion stationary.

1003.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite right,—that is, on the supposition that some classes mingle with one another, and others not.

1004.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: That such a communion of kinds is according to nature, we had already proved before we arrived at this part of our discussion.

1005.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

1006.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let us proceed, then.
May we not say that motion is other than the other, having been also proved by us to be other than the same and other than rest?

1007.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is certain.

1008.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then, according to this view, motion is other and also not other?

1009.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1010.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: What is the next step?
Shall we say that motion is other than the three and not other than the fourth,—for we agreed that there are five classes about and in the sphere of which we proposed to make enquiry?

1011.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Surely we cannot admit that the number is less than it appeared to be just now.

1012.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then we may without fear contend that motion is other than being?

1013.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Without the least fear.

1014.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The plain result is that motion, since it partakes of being, really is and also is not?

1015.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Nothing can be plainer.

1016.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then not-being necessarily exists in the case of motion and of every class; for the nature of the other entering into them all, makes each of them other than being, and so non-existent; and therefore of all of them, in like manner, we may truly say that they are not; and again, inasmuch as they partake of being, that they are and are existent.

1017.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: So we may assume.

1018.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Every class, then, has plurality of being and infinity of not-being.

1019.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: So we must infer.

1020.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And being itself may be said to be other than the other kinds.

1021.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

1022.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then we may infer that being is not, in respect of as many other things as there are; for not-being these it is itself one, and is not the other things, which are infinite in number.

1023.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is not far from the truth.

1024.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And we must not quarrel with this result, since it is of the nature of classes to have communion with one another; and if any one denies our present statement [viz., that being is not, etc.
], let him first argue with our former conclusion [i.e., respecting the communion of ideas], and then he may proceed to argue with what follows.

1025.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Nothing can be fairer.

1026.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let me ask you to consider a further question.

1027.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What question?

1028.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When we speak of not-being, we speak, I suppose, not of something opposed to being, but only different.

1029.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What do you mean?

1030.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When we speak of something as not great, does the expression seem to you to imply what is little any more than what is equal?

1031.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly not.

1032.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The negative particles, ou and me, when prefixed to words, do not imply opposition, but only difference from the words, or more correctly from the things represented by the words, which follow them.

1033.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

1034.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: There is another point to be considered, if you do not object.

1035.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What is it?

1036.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The nature of the other appears to me to be divided into fractions like knowledge.

1037.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How so?

1038.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Knowledge, like the other, is one; and yet the various parts of knowledge have each of them their own particular name, and hence there are many arts and kinds of knowledge.

1039.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

1040.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And is not the case the same with the parts of the other, which is also one?

1041.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very likely; but will you tell me how?

1042.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: There is some part of the other which is opposed to the beautiful?

1043.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: There is.

1044.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Shall we say that this has or has not a name?

1045.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: It has; for whatever we call not-beautiful is other than the beautiful, not than something else.

1046.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And now tell me another thing.

1047.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What?

1048.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Is the not-beautiful anything but this—an existence parted off from a certain kind of existence, and again from another point of view opposed to an existing something?

1049.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1050.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then the not-beautiful turns out to be the opposition of being to being?

1051.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very true.

1052.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But upon this view, is the beautiful a more real and the not-beautiful a less real existence?

1053.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Not at all.

1054.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the not-great may be said to exist, equally with the great?

1055.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1056.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And, in the same way, the just must be placed in the same category with the not-just—the one cannot be said to have any more existence than the other.

1057.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1058.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The same may be said of other things; seeing that the nature of the other has a real existence, the parts of this nature must equally be supposed to exist.

1059.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of course.

1060.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then, as would appear, the opposition of a part of the other, and of a part of being, to one another, is, if I may venture to say so, as truly essence as being itself, and implies not the opposite of being, but only what is other than being.

1061.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Beyond question.

1062.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: What then shall we call it?

1063.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Clearly, not-being; and this is the very nature for which the Sophist compelled us to search.

1064.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And has not this, as you were saying, as real an existence as any other class?
May I not say with confidence that not-being has an assured existence, and a nature of its own?

Just as the great was found to be great and the beautiful beautiful, and the not-great not-great, and the not-beautiful not-beautiful, in the same manner not-being has been found to be and is not-being, and is to be reckoned one among the many classes of being.
Do you, Theaetetus, still feel any doubt of this?

1065.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: None whatever.

1066.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Do you observe that our scepticism has carried us beyond the range of Parmenides' prohibition?

1067.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: In what?

1068.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: We have advanced to a further point, and shown him more than he forbad us to investigate.

1069.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How is that?

1070.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Why, because he says—
'Not-being never is, and do thou keep thy thoughts from this way of enquiry.'

1072.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, he says so.

1073.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Whereas, we have not only proved that things which are not are, but we have shown what form of being not-being is; for we have shown that the nature of the other is, and is distributed over all things in their relations to one another, and whatever part of the other is contrasted with being, this is precisely what we have ventured to call not-being.

1074.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: And surely, Stranger, we were quite right.

1075.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let not any one say, then, that while affirming the opposition of not-being to being, we still assert the being of not-being; for as to whether there is an opposite of being, to that enquiry we have long said good-bye—it may or may not be, and may or may not be capable of definition.

But as touching our present account of not-being, let a man either convince us of error, or, so long as he cannot, he too must say, as we are saying, that there is a communion of classes, and that being, and difference or other, traverse all things and mutually interpenetrate, so that the other partakes of being, and by reason of this participation is, and yet is not that of which it partakes, but other, and being other than being, it is clearly a necessity that not-being should be.

And again, being, through partaking of the other, becomes a class other than the remaining classes, and being other than all of them, is not each one of them, and is not all the rest, so that undoubtedly there are thousands upon thousands of cases in which being is not, and all other things, whether regarded individually or collectively, in many respects are, and in many respects are not.

1076.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1077.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And he who is sceptical of this contradiction, must think how he can find something better to say; or if he sees a puzzle, and his pleasure is to drag words this way and that, the argument will prove to him, that he is not making a worthy use of his faculties; for there is no charm in such puzzles, and there is no difficulty in detecting them; but we can tell him of something else the pursuit of which is noble and also difficult.

1078.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What is it?

1079.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: A thing of which I have already spoken;—letting alone these puzzles as involving no difficulty, he should be able to follow and criticize in detail every argument, and when a man says that the same is in a manner other, or that other is the same, to understand and refute him from his own point of view, and in the same respect in which he asserts either of these affections.

But to show that somehow and in some sense the same is other, or the other same, or the great small, or the like unlike; and to delight in always bringing forward such contradictions, is no real refutation, but is clearly the new-born babe of some one who is only beginning to approach the problem of being.

1080.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: To be sure.

1081.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: For certainly, my friend, the attempt to separate all existences from one another is a barbarism and utterly unworthy of an educated or philosophical mind.

1082.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Why so?

1083.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The attempt at universal separation is the final annihilation of all reasoning; for only by the union of conceptions with one another do we attain to discourse of reason.

1084.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1085.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And, observe that we were only just in time in making a resistance to such separatists, and compelling them to admit that one thing mingles with another.

1086.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Why so?

1087.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Why, that we might be able to assert discourse to be a kind of being; for if we could not, the worst of all consequences would follow; we should have no philosophy.

Moreover, the necessity for determining the nature of discourse presses upon us at this moment; if utterly deprived of it, we could no more hold discourse; and deprived of it we should be if we admitted that there was no admixture of natures at all.

1088.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very true.
But I do not understand why at this moment we must determine the nature of discourse.

1089.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Perhaps you will see more clearly by the help of the following explanation.

1090.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What explanation?

1091.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Not-being has been acknowledged by us to be one among many classes diffused over all being.

1092.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1093.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And thence arises the question, whether not-being mingles with opinion and language.

1094.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How so?

1095.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: If not-being has no part in the proposition, then all things must be true; but if not-being has a part, then false opinion and false speech are possible, for to think or to say what is not—is falsehood, which thus arises in the region of thought and in speech.

1096.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That is quite true.

1097.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And where there is falsehood surely there must be deceit.

1098.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1099.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And if there is deceit, then all things must be full of idols and images and fancies.

1100.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: To be sure.

1101.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Into that region the Sophist, as we said, made his escape, and, when he had got there, denied the very possibility of falsehood; no one, he argued, either conceived or uttered falsehood, inasmuch as not-being did not in any way partake of being.

1102.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1103.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And now, not-being has been shown to partake of being, and therefore he will not continue fighting in this direction, but he will probably say that some ideas partake of not-being, and some not, and that language and opinion are of the non-partaking class; and he will still fight to the death against the existence of the image-making and phantastic art, in which we have placed him, because, as he will say, opinion and language do not partake of not-being, and unless this participation exists, there can be no such thing as falsehood.

And, with the view of meeting this evasion, we must begin by enquiring into the nature of language, opinion, and imagination, in order that when we find them we may find also that they have communion with not-being, and, having made out the connexion of them, may thus prove that falsehood exists; and therein we will imprison the Sophist, if he deserves it, or, if not, we will let him go again and look for him in another class.

1104.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly, Stranger, there appears to be truth in what was said about the Sophist at first, that he was of a class not easily caught, for he seems to have abundance of defences, which he throws up, and which must every one of them be stormed before we can reach the man himself.
And even now, we have with difficulty got through his first defence, which is the not-being of not-being, and lo!
here is another; for we have still to show that falsehood exists in the sphere of language and opinion, and there will be another and another line of defence without end.

1105.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Any one, Theaetetus, who is able to advance even a little ought to be of good cheer, for what would he who is dispirited at a little progress do, if he were making none at all, or even undergoing a repulse?
Such a faint heart, as the proverb says, will never take a city:  but now that we have succeeded thus far, the citadel is ours, and what remains is easier.

1106.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very true.

1107.speaker: STRANGER
