sentences: Then, as I was saying, let us first of all obtain a conception of language and opinion, in order that we may have clearer grounds for determining, whether not-being has any concern with them, or whether they are both always true, and neither of them ever false.

1108.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1109.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then, now, let us speak of names, as before we were speaking of ideas and letters; for that is the direction in which the answer may be expected.

1110.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: And what is the question at issue about names?

1111.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The question at issue is whether all names may be connected with one another, or none, or only some of them.

1112.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Clearly the last is true.

1113.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I understand you to say that words which have a meaning when in sequence may be connected, but that words which have no meaning when in sequence cannot be connected?

1114.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What are you saying?

1115.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: What I thought that you intended when you gave your assent; for there are two sorts of intimation of being which are given by the voice.

1116.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What are they?

1117.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: One of them is called nouns, and the other verbs.

1118.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Describe them.

1119.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: That which denotes action we call a verb.

1120.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1121.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the other, which is an articulate mark set on those who do the actions, we call a noun.

1122.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

1123.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: A succession of nouns only is not a sentence, any more than of verbs without nouns.

1124.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I do not understand you.

1125.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I see that when you gave your assent you had something else in your mind.
But what I intended to say was, that a mere succession of nouns or of verbs is not discourse.

1126.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What do you mean?

1127.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I mean that words like 'walks,' 'runs,' 'sleeps,' or any other words which denote action, however many of them you string together, do not make discourse.

1128.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How can they?

1129.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Or, again, when you say 'lion,' 'stag,' 'horse,' or any other words which denote agents—neither in this way of stringing words together do you attain to discourse; for there is no expression of action or inaction, or of the existence of existence or non-existence indicated by the sounds, until verbs are mingled with nouns; then the words fit, and the smallest combination of them forms language, and is the simplest and least form of discourse.

1130.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Again I ask, What do you mean?

1131.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When any one says 'A man learns,' should you not call this the simplest and least of sentences?

1132.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1133.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Yes, for he now arrives at the point of giving an intimation about something which is, or is becoming, or has become, or will be.
And he not only names, but he does something, by connecting verbs with nouns; and therefore we say that he discourses, and to this connexion of words we give the name of discourse.

1134.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1135.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And as there are some things which fit one another, and other things which do not fit, so there are some vocal signs which do, and others which do not, combine and form discourse.

1136.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

1137.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: There is another small matter.

1138.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What is it?

1139.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: A sentence must and cannot help having a subject.

1140.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1141.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And must be of a certain quality.

1142.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

1143.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And now let us mind what we are about.

1144.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: We must do so.

1145.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I will repeat a sentence to you in which a thing and an action are combined, by the help of a noun and a verb; and you shall tell me of whom the sentence speaks.

1146.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I will, to the best of my power.

1147.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: 'Theaetetus sits'—not a very long sentence.

1148.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Not very.

1149.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Of whom does the sentence speak, and who is the subject?
that is what you have to tell.

1150.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Of me; I am the subject.

1151.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Or this sentence, again—

1152.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What sentence?

1153.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: 'Theaetetus, with whom I am now speaking, is flying.'

1154.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: That also is a sentence which will be admitted by every one to speak of me, and to apply to me.

1155.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: We agreed that every sentence must necessarily have a certain quality.

1156.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1157.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And what is the quality of each of these two sentences?

1158.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: The one, as I imagine, is false, and the other true.

1159.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The true says what is true about you?

1160.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1161.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the false says what is other than true?

1162.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1163.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And therefore speaks of things which are not as if they were?

1164.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1165.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And say that things are real of you which are not; for, as we were saying, in regard to each thing or person, there is much that is and much that is not.

1166.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

1167.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The second of the two sentences which related to you was first of all an example of the shortest form consistent with our definition.

1168.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, this was implied in recent admission.

1169.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And, in the second place, it related to a subject?

1170.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1171.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Who must be you, and can be nobody else?

1172.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Unquestionably.

1173.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And it would be no sentence at all if there were no subject, for, as we proved, a sentence which has no subject is impossible.

1174.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

1175.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When other, then, is asserted of you as the same, and not-being as being, such a combination of nouns and verbs is really and truly false discourse.

1176.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Most true.

1177.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And therefore thought, opinion, and imagination are now proved to exist in our minds both as true and false.

1178.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How so?

1179.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: You will know better if you first gain a knowledge of what they are, and in what they severally differ from one another.

1180.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Give me the knowledge which you would wish me to gain.

1181.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Are not thought and speech the same, with this exception, that what is called thought is the unuttered conversation of the soul with herself?

1182.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

1183.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But the stream of thought which flows through the lips and is audible is called speech?

1184.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1185.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And we know that there exists in speech...

1186.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What exists?

1187.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Affirmation.

1188.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, we know it.

1189.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When the affirmation or denial takes Place in silence and in the mind only, have you any other name by which to call it but opinion?

1190.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: There can be no other name.

1191.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And when opinion is presented, not simply, but in some form of sense, would you not call it imagination?

1192.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

1193.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And seeing that language is true and false, and that thought is the conversation of the soul with herself, and opinion is the end of thinking, and imagination or phantasy is the union of sense and opinion, the inference is that some of them, since they are akin to language, should have an element of falsehood as well as of truth?

1194.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Certainly.

1195.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Do you perceive, then, that false opinion and speech have been discovered sooner than we expected?—For just now we seemed to be undertaking a task which would never be accomplished.

1196.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I perceive.

1197.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then let us not be discouraged about the future; but now having made this discovery, let us go back to our previous classification.

1198.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What classification?

1199.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: We divided image-making into two sorts; the one likeness-making, the other imaginative or phantastic.

1200.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1201.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And we said that we were uncertain in which we should place the Sophist.

1202.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: We did say so.

1203.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And our heads began to go round more and more when it was asserted that there is no such thing as an image or idol or appearance, because in no manner or time or place can there ever be such a thing as falsehood.

1204.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1205.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And now, since there has been shown to be false speech and false opinion, there may be imitations of real existences, and out of this condition of the mind an art of deception may arise.

1206.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite possible.

1207.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And we have already admitted, in what preceded, that the Sophist was lurking in one of the divisions of the likeness-making art?

1208.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1209.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let us, then, renew the attempt, and in dividing any class, always take the part to the right, holding fast to that which holds the Sophist, until we have stripped him of all his common properties, and reached his difference or peculiar.
Then we may exhibit him in his true nature, first to ourselves and then to kindred dialectical spirits.

1210.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very good.

1211.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: You may remember that all art was originally divided by us into creative and acquisitive.

1212.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1213.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And the Sophist was flitting before us in the acquisitive class, in the subdivisions of hunting, contests, merchandize, and the like.

1214.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very true.

1215.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: But now that the imitative art has enclosed him, it is clear that we must begin by dividing the art of creation; for imitation is a kind of creation—of images, however, as we affirm, and not of real things.

1216.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

1217.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: In the first place, there are two kinds of creation.

1218.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What are they?

1219.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: One of them is human and the other divine.

1220.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I do not follow.

1221.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Every power, as you may remember our saying originally, which causes things to exist, not previously existing, was defined by us as creative.

1222.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I remember.

1223.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Looking, now, at the world and all the animals and plants, at things which grow upon the earth from seeds and roots, as well as at inanimate substances which are formed within the earth, fusile or non-fusile, shall we say that they come into existence—not having existed previously—by the creation of God, or shall we agree with vulgar opinion about them?

1224.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What is it?

1225.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The opinion that nature brings them into being from some spontaneous and unintelligent cause.
Or shall we say that they are created by a divine reason and a knowledge which comes from God?

1226.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I dare say that, owing to my youth, I may often waver in my view, but now when I look at you and see that you incline to refer them to God, I defer to your authority.

1227.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Nobly said, Theaetetus, and if I thought that you were one of those who would hereafter change your mind, I would have gently argued with you, and forced you to assent; but as I perceive that you will come of yourself and without any argument of mine, to that belief which, as you say, attracts you, I will not forestall the work of time.
Let me suppose, then, that things which are said to be made by nature are the work of divine art, and that things which are made by man out of these are works of human art.
And so there are two kinds of making and production, the one human and the other divine.

1228.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1229.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then, now, subdivide each of the two sections which we have already.

1230.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: How do you mean?

1231.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I mean to say that you should make a vertical division of production or invention, as you have already made a lateral one.

1232.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: I have done so.

1233.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then, now, there are in all four parts or segments—two of them have reference to us and are human, and two of them have reference to the gods and are divine.

1234.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1235.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And, again, in the division which was supposed to be made in the other way, one part in each subdivision is the making of the things themselves, but the two remaining parts may be called the making of likenesses; and so the productive art is again divided into two parts.

1236.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Tell me the divisions once more.

1237.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: I suppose that we, and the other animals, and the elements out of which things are made—fire, water, and the like—are known by us to be each and all the creation and work of God.

1238.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1239.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And there are images of them, which are not them, but which correspond to them; and these are also the creation of a wonderful skill.

1240.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What are they?

1241.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The appearances which spring up of themselves in sleep or by day, such as a shadow when darkness arises in a fire, or the reflection which is produced when the light in bright and smooth objects meets on their surface with an external light, and creates a perception the opposite of our ordinary sight.

1242.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes; and the images as well as the creation are equally the work of a divine hand.

1243.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And what shall we say of human art?
Do we not make one house by the art of building, and another by the art of drawing, which is a sort of dream created by man for those who are awake?

1244.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Quite true.

1245.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And other products of human creation are also twofold and go in pairs; there is the thing, with which the art of making the thing is concerned, and the image, with which imitation is concerned.

1246.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Now I begin to understand, and am ready to acknowledge that there are two kinds of production, and each of them twofold; in the lateral division there is both a divine and a human production; in the vertical there are realities and a creation of a kind of similitudes.

1247.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And let us not forget that of the imitative class the one part was to have been likeness-making, and the other phantastic, if it could be shown that falsehood is a reality and belongs to the class of real being.

1248.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1249.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And this appeared to be the case; and therefore now, without hesitation, we shall number the different kinds as two.

1250.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1251.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Then, now, let us again divide the phantastic art.

1252.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Where shall we make the division?

1253.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: There is one kind which is produced by an instrument, and another in which the creator of the appearance is himself the instrument.

1254.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What do you mean?

1255.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: When any one makes himself appear like another in his figure or his voice, imitation is the name for this part of the phantastic art.

1256.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes.

1257.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let this, then, be named the art of mimicry, and this the province assigned to it; as for the other division, we are weary and will give that up, leaving to some one else the duty of making the class and giving it a suitable name.

1258.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Let us do as you say—assign a sphere to the one and leave the other.

1259.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: There is a further distinction, Theaetetus, which is worthy of our consideration, and for a reason which I will tell you.

1260.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Let me hear.

1261.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: There are some who imitate, knowing what they imitate, and some who do not know.
And what line of distinction can there possibly be greater than that which divides ignorance from knowledge?

1262.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: There can be no greater.

1263.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Was not the sort of imitation of which we spoke just now the imitation of those who know?
For he who would imitate you would surely know you and your figure?

1264.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Naturally.

1265.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And what would you say of the figure or form of justice or of virtue in general?

Are we not well aware that many, having no knowledge of either, but only a sort of opinion, do their best to show that this opinion is really entertained by them, by expressing it, as far as they can, in word and deed?

1266.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Yes, that is very common.

1267.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And do they always fail in their attempt to be thought just, when they are not?
Or is not the very opposite true?

1268.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: The very opposite.

1269.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Such a one, then, should be described as an imitator—to be distinguished from the other, as he who is ignorant is distinguished from him who knows?

1270.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: True.

1271.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Can we find a suitable name for each of them?

This is clearly not an easy task; for among the ancients there was some confusion of ideas, which prevented them from attempting to divide genera into species; wherefore there is no great abundance of names.
Yet, for the sake of distinctness, I will make bold to call the imitation which coexists with opinion, the imitation of appearance—that which coexists with science, a scientific or learned imitation.

1272.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Granted.

1273.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: The former is our present concern, for the Sophist was classed with imitators indeed, but not among those who have knowledge.

1274.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very true.

1275.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Let us, then, examine our imitator of appearance, and see whether he is sound, like a piece of iron, or whether there is still some crack in him.

1276.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Let us examine him.

1277.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Indeed there is a very considerable crack; for if you look, you find that one of the two classes of imitators is a simple creature, who thinks that he knows that which he only fancies; the other sort has knocked about among arguments, until he suspects and fears that he is ignorant of that which to the many he pretends to know.

1278.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: There are certainly the two kinds which you describe.

1279.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Shall we regard one as the simple imitator—the other as the dissembling or ironical imitator?

1280.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Very good.

1281.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And shall we further speak of this latter class as having one or two divisions?

1282.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Answer yourself.

1283.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Upon consideration, then, there appear to me to be two; there is the dissembler, who harangues a multitude in public in a long speech, and the dissembler, who in private and in short speeches compels the person who is conversing with him to contradict himself.

1284.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: What you say is most true.

1285.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And who is the maker of the longer speeches?
Is he the statesman or the popular orator?

1286.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: The latter.

1287.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: And what shall we call the other?
Is he the philosopher or the Sophist?

1288.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: The philosopher he cannot be, for upon our view he is ignorant; but since he is an imitator of the wise he will have a name which is formed by an adaptation of the word sophos.
What shall we name him?
I am pretty sure that I cannot be mistaken in terming him the true and very Sophist.

1289.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: Shall we bind up his name as we did before, making a chain from one end of his genealogy to the other?

1290.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: By all means.

1291.speaker: STRANGER
sentences: He, then, who traces the pedigree of his art as follows—who, belonging to the conscious or dissembling section of the art of causing self-contradiction, is an imitator of appearance, and is separated from the class of phantastic which is a branch of image-making into that further division of creation, the juggling of words, a creation human, and not divine—any one who affirms the real Sophist to be of this blood and lineage will say the very truth.

1292.speaker: THEAETETUS
sentences: Undoubtedly.
